ground_truth: He stops, looks down at Lampert's body for a moment, then suddenly sneezes six times in rapid succession. He takes a small bottle from his pocket, shakes a pill from it, and swallows it dry. He turns and walks back up the aisle, looking for a place to sit. He comes face to face with Grandpierre, stops, and turns to sit somewhere else. Again, the sound of the door opening interrupts them, and they turn to look. The figure of a man, outlined in silhouette against the outside brightness, wears a velvet-corduroy suit, string tie, and a bright yellow flower in his lapel. A bulldurham tag hangs from his outside breast pocket, dangling from its string. He starts down the aisle toward the bier, camera leading him, and we notice his unsteady gait. He turns to look at the others present, moving down the aisle. Grandpierre's face, then Gideon's, then Reggie's, and Sylvie's—all stare at the camera as Tex arrives. He stands staring at Lampert's body, swaying on his feet until he reaches out and grabs the side of the coffin to steady himself. Then he takes the flower from his lapel and throws it into the open box. Sylvie points to Reggie, and unruffled, Tex starts over, addressing Reggie this time. She pulls out the letter and starts to read it. It bears the Great Seal as a letterhead, and the typed message reads. Sylvie has been reading over Reggie's shoulder. The elevator door closes on them, and Reggie reacts to this, starting down the hall, finally stopping at the door. The office is empty, the typewriter on the secretary's desk covered with its plastic shroud. Reggie enters, looks for somebody, and notices that the door to the private office is slightly ajar. Bartholomew comes to the door and looks in. He is a pale, grey-haired man who looks, on first examination, older than his forty-odd years; sickly would be the word that describes him best—pallid, consumptive-looking. He wears heavy tortoise-framed glasses that fall down his nose and cause him to push them back in place every so often with a quick automatic motion. He motions for her to enter, standing aside to let her do so. A small cubicle has a silver-framed photo of three kids on the desk. A can of lighter fluid stands open on the desk and a crumpled hankie beside it. He works at a stain on his necktie with lighter fluid and hankie. He looks up at her, laughs silently, then goes back to his tie. He puts away the lighter fluid in a desk drawer, smells the hankie, passes on it, then sticks it in his pocket.

test_cases.name: Synonym Substitution
test_cases.description: He pauses, glances down at Lampert's corpse for an instant, then abruptly sneezes six instances in quick series. He retrieves a little vial from his pocket, dislodges a tablet from it, and ingests it dry. He rotates and strides back up the passage, searching for a spot to seat. He encounters Grandpierre directly, halts, and pivots to seat elsewhere. Again, the sound of the portal opening disrupts them, and they rotate to glance. The silhouette of a man, outlined against the exterior brilliance, dons a velvet-corduroy ensemble, string necktie, and a vivid yellow blossom in his lapel. A bulldurham tag suspends from his exterior chest pocket, dangling from its string. He begins down the passage toward the bier, camera preceding him, and we observe his unstable stride. He rotates to glance at the others present, proceeding down the passage. Grandpierre's visage, then Gideon's, then Reggie's, and Sylvie's—all gaze at the camera as Tex arrives. He stands gazing at Lampert's corpse, swaying on his feet until he reaches out and clutches the side of the coffin to stabilize himself. Then he takes the blossom from his lapel and tosses it into the open box. Sylvie indicates Reggie, and unperturbed, Tex begins anew, addressing Reggie this instance. She extracts the letter and begins to recite it. It bears the Great Seal as a letterhead, and the typed message states. Sylvie has been reading over Reggie's shoulder. The elevator portal closes on them, and Reggie reacts to this, commencing down the corridor, ultimately halting at the portal. The office is vacant, the typewriter on the secretary's desk shrouded with its plastic covering. Reggie enters, searches for someone, and observes that the portal to the private office is slightly ajar. Bartholomew approaches the portal and glances in. He is a pale, grey-haired gentleman who appears, on first inspection, older than his forty-some years; sickly would be the term that describes him best—pallid, consumptive-looking. He dons heavy tortoise-framed spectacles that slip down his nose and cause him to nudge them back in position every so frequently with a swift automatic gesture. He signals for her to enter, standing aside to permit her to do so. A small cubicle has a silver-framed photograph of three children on the desk. A can of lighter fluid stands ajar on the desk and a crumpled hankie beside it. He operates on a blemish on his necktie with lighter fluid and hankie. He glances up at her, chuckles silently, then returns to his tie. He stores the lighter fluid in a desk drawer, sniffs the hankie, declines it, then inserts it in his pocket.

test_cases.name: Active <-> Passive Transformation
test_cases.description: He is stopped, and Lampert's body is looked down at by him for a moment; then he suddenly sneezes six times in rapid succession. A small bottle is taken from his pocket by him, a pill is shaken from it, and it is swallowed dry by him. He turns and walks back up the aisle, looking for a place to sit. Grandpierre is faced by him, and he is stopped, then he turns to sit somewhere else. Again, the sound of the door opening interrupts them, and a look is turned by them. The figure of a man, outlined in silhouette against the outside brightness, wears a velvet-corduroy suit, string tie, and a bright yellow flower in his lapel. A bulldurham tag hangs from his outside breast pocket, dangling from its string. Down the aisle is started by him toward the bier, leading himself with a camera, and his unsteady gait is noticed by us. The others present are looked at by him, moving down the aisle. The camera is stared at by Grandpierre's face, then Gideon's, then Reggie's, and Sylvie's—all as Tex arrives. Lampert's body is stared at by him while swaying on his feet until the side of the coffin is reached out to and grabbed by him to steady himself. The flower is then taken from his lapel by him and is thrown into the open box. Reggie is pointed to by Sylvie, and unruffled, Tex starts over, addressing Reggie this time. The letter is pulled out by her and it is started to be read. The Great Seal as a letterhead is borne by it, and the typed message is read. Reggie's shoulder is read over by Sylvie. The elevator door is closed on them, and Reggie reacts to this, starting down the hall and finally stopping at the door. The office is empty, the typewriter on the secretary's desk covered with its plastic shroud. Somebody is looked for by Reggie as she enters, and she notices that the door to the private office is slightly ajar. The door is reached by Bartholomew, and he looks in. A pale, grey-haired man who looks, on first examination, older than his forty-odd years; sickly would be the word that describes him best—pallid, consumptive-looking. Heavy tortoise-framed glasses that fall down his nose and cause him to push them back in place every so often with a quick automatic motion are worn by him. He stands aside to let her enter, motioning for her to do so. A small cubicle has a silver-framed photo of three kids on the desk. On the desk stands a can of lighter fluid, open, and a crumpled hankie beside it. A stain on his necktie is worked at by him with lighter fluid and hankie. At her, he looks up, laughs silently, then goes back to his tie. The lighter fluid is put away in a desk drawer by him, the hankie is smelled, passed on, then it is stuck in his pocket.

test_cases.name: Brevity - L1
test_cases.description: He pauses, glances at Lampert's body, then sneezes six times quickly. He takes a bottle from his pocket, swallows a pill dry, and walks back up the aisle, seeking a seat. Encountering Grandpierre, he turns to sit elsewhere. The door opens again, revealing a man silhouetted against the bright light, dressed in a velvet-corduroy suit with a string tie and bright yellow lapel flower, and a bulldurham tag dangling from his pocket. He walks unsteadily down the aisle toward the bier, the camera following him. He scans the room, meeting the gazes of Grandpierre, Gideon, Reggie, and Sylvie as he reaches Lampert's body. He sways, steadies himself by gripping the coffin, and tosses his flower inside. Sylvie gestures to Reggie as Tex begins speaking to her. Reggie pulls out a letter bearing the Great Seal and starts reading. Sylvie reads over her shoulder. The elevator doors close on them, prompting Reggie to head down the hall and stop at a door. The empty office has a typewriter covered in plastic on the secretary's desk. Reggie enters, searching for someone, noticing the private office door is slightly open. Bartholomew, a pale, sickly-looking man with grey hair and heavy tortoise-framed glasses, appears. He motions for her to enter. On a desk in the small cubicle are a silver-framed photo of three kids, an open can of lighter fluid, and a crumpled hankie. He works on a stain on his necktie with the fluid and hankie, silently laughs, then resumes his task. He puts the fluid away, smells the hankie, declines it, and pockets it.

test_cases.name: Brevity - L2
test_cases.description: He pauses, glances at Lampert's body, then sneezes six times rapidly. He swallows a pill dry from a pocketed bottle, walks up the aisle seeking a seat, encounters Grandpierre, and moves elsewhere. The door opens, revealing a man in a velvet-corduroy suit with a string tie and yellow flower. A bulldurham tag dangles from his pocket. As he nears the bier, the camera captures his unsteady steps. He scans faces: Grandpierre, Gideon, Reggie, and Sylvie as he reaches Lampert, sways, steadies himself, and tosses the flower into the coffin. Sylvie points at Reggie; Tex addresses her. Reggie reads a letter with the Great Seal, while Sylvie peers over her shoulder. The elevator door shuts, prompting Reggie to head down the hall, stopping at the office door. Inside is empty, a shrouded typewriter on the secretary's desk. Reggie enters, notices the private office door ajar. Bartholomew, a pale, grey-haired man looking older than forty, with sickly, pallid skin, appears. His tortoise-framed glasses frequently slip down his nose, which he adjusts habitually. He invites Reggie in, revealing a small cubicle with a silver-framed photo of three kids, open lighter fluid, and a crumpled hankie. He treats a tie stain with lighter fluid and hankie, silently laughs, then stores the fluid and pockets the hankie.

test_cases.name: Verbosity - L1
test_cases.description: He halts abruptly and briefly gazes down at Lampert's lifeless body with a pensive expression, then is seized by a sudden bout of sneezing, erupting six times in rapid succession. Reaching into his pocket, he retrieves a small bottle, gives it a little shake to release a single pill, and swallows it without any water. With a purposeful turn, he strides back up the aisle, scanning the surroundings for a suitable place to sit. As he continues, he unexpectedly comes face to face with Grandpierre, which causes him to pause momentarily, then pivot in search of another seating option. Once more, the sound of the door creaking open disrupts their attention, prompting them to turn and see what has occurred. The silhouette of a man is outlined against the glaring brightness of the outside light, attired in an unusual velvet-corduroy suit, complemented by a string tie and an eye-catching bright yellow flower pinned to his lapel. A tag from Bull Durham dangles conspicuously from the outside breast pocket, swinging slightly from its string as he starts his way down the aisle towards the bier, with the camera closely following his movements. We take notice of his unsteady, almost wavering gait as he proceeds. He casts his gaze at the assembled individuals while making his way down the aisle: Grandpierre's face, then Gideon's, then Reggie's, and Sylvie's—all fix their eyes on the camera as Tex finally arrives. Upon reaching Lampert's body, he stands there, seemingly mesmerized, swaying slightly on his feet until he grasps the side of the coffin for support. Then, in a ceremonious gesture, he removes the vibrant flower from his lapel and tosses it gently into the open box. Sylvie points deliberately towards Reggie, and with a calm, unperturbed demeanor, Tex approaches, this time addressing Reggie. She, in turn, pulls out a letter, preparing to read aloud. The letter, distinguished by the Great Seal emblazoned as a letterhead, contains a typed message. Sylvie has been leaning over Reggie's shoulder, following along with her reading. As the elevator doors slide shut with a soft thud, Reggie reacts to this, briskly making her way down the hallway, ultimately halting at a door. The office she enters is devoid of people, with the typewriter on the secretary's desk concealed under a protective plastic shroud. Reggie steps inside, scanning the space for any sign of someone, then notes that the door to the private office is slightly ajar, inviting curiosity. Bartholomew appears at the threshold and peers inside. He is a pale, grey-haired man whose initial impression is of someone older than his actual forty-some years; the word "sickly" might best describe his appearance, with a pallid, consumptive look. He wears heavy, tortoise-framed glasses that perpetually slide down his nose, prompting him to push them back up with a swift, automatic motion. Gesturing for her to enter, he steps aside to allow her passage. Inside the small cubicle, a silver-framed photograph of three children is prominently displayed on the desk. An open can of lighter fluid and a crumpled handkerchief lie beside it. He is occupied with removing a stain from his necktie using the lighter fluid and the handkerchief. Briefly looking up at her, he emits a silent laugh before returning to the task at hand. Afterward, he places the lighter fluid back into a desk drawer, then sniffs the handkerchief, dismisses it with a slight frown, and finally tucks it back into his pocket.

test_cases.name: Verbosity - L2
test_cases.description: He halts abruptly in his tracks and briefly gazes down at Lampert's lifeless body, wearing a pensive expression that hints at his inner thoughts. Suddenly, he is seized by an uncontrollable bout of sneezing, erupting six times in rapid succession, each sneeze echoing through the room. Reaching into the depths of his pocket, he retrieves a small bottle, gives it a little shake to release a solitary pill, and swallows it without the aid of any water. With a purposeful turn, he strides back up the aisle, scanning the surroundings intently for a suitable place to sit and rest. As he continues his search, he unexpectedly comes face to face with Grandpierre, which causes him to pause momentarily, then pivot on his heels in search of another seating option. Once more, the sound of the door creaking open disrupts their attention, prompting them to turn and see what has occurred in the space. The silhouette of a man is outlined against the glaring brightness of the outside light, attired in an unusual velvet-corduroy suit that sets him apart, complemented by a string tie and an eye-catching bright yellow flower pinned to his lapel. A tag from Bull Durham dangles conspicuously from the outside breast pocket, swinging slightly from its string as he starts his deliberate way down the aisle towards the bier, with the camera closely following his movements. We take notice of his unsteady, almost wavering gait as he proceeds along the path. He casts his gaze at the assembled individuals while making his way down the aisle: Grandpierre's face, then Gideon's, then Reggie's, and finally Sylvie's—all of them fix their eyes on the camera as Tex finally arrives at his destination. Upon reaching the presence of Lampert's body, he stands there, seemingly mesmerized, swaying slightly on his feet until he grasps the side of the coffin for support and stability. Then, in a ceremonious gesture, he removes the vibrant flower from his lapel and tosses it gently into the open box. Sylvie points deliberately towards Reggie, and with a calm, unperturbed demeanor, Tex approaches, this time addressing Reggie directly. She, in turn, reaches into her belongings to pull out a letter, preparing herself to read it aloud to the attentive audience. The letter, distinguished by the Great Seal emblazoned as a letterhead, contains a typed message. Sylvie has been leaning over Reggie's shoulder, following along intently with her reading. As the elevator doors slide shut with a soft, final thud, Reggie reacts swiftly to this, briskly making her way down the long hallway, ultimately halting at a door. The office she enters is devoid of people, with the typewriter resting on the secretary's desk concealed under a protective plastic shroud. Reggie steps inside, her eyes scanning the space for any sign of someone, then takes note that the door to the private office is slightly ajar, inviting curiosity to pique her interest. Bartholomew appears at the threshold and peers inside. He is a pale, grey-haired man whose initial impression is of someone older than his actual forty-some years; the word "sickly" might best describe his appearance, with a pallid, consumptive look that suggests frailty. He wears heavy, tortoise-framed glasses that perpetually slide down his nose, prompting him to push them back up with a swift, automatic motion. Gesturing for her to enter, he steps aside to allow her passage into the room. Inside the small cubicle, a silver-framed photograph of three children is prominently displayed on the desk, capturing attention. An open can of lighter fluid and a crumpled handkerchief lie beside it. He is occupied with the task of removing a stubborn stain from his necktie using the lighter fluid and the handkerchief. Briefly looking up at her, he emits a silent, knowing laugh before returning his focus to the task at hand. Afterward, he places the lighter fluid back into a desk drawer, then sniffs the handkerchief with a discerning frown, dismisses it with a slight frown, and finally tucks it back into his pocket.

test_cases.name: Macro-Actions -> Micro-Actions
test_cases.description: He comes to a halt, directing his gaze downward to fix his eyes on Lampert's lifeless body, his attention lingering for a brief moment, until an unexpected tickle in his nose triggers six rapid sneezes in succession. Once the fit subsides, he retrieves a small bottle from his pocket, gives it a slight shake, allowing a single pill to fall into his palm. He immediately pops the pill into his mouth and swallows it without the aid of water. With the pill ingested, he pivots and begins making his way back up the aisle, his eyes scanning for an available seat. As he continues along the path, he suddenly encounters Grandpierre directly in his path, prompting him to halt abruptly, pivot away from the man, and seek another seating option. Just then, a noise disrupts the scene—the distinct sound of a door creaking open captures their attention, causing them to turn their heads toward the source. In the doorway stands a figure, backlit by a flood of bright light from outside, the silhouette revealing a man attired in a velvet-corduroy suit and a string tie, with a vibrant yellow flower pinned to his lapel. Dangling conspicuously from a string attached to his breast pocket is a bulldurham tag. He begins his advance down the aisle, a camera capturing his movements, and his unsteady gait draws attention with each step. As he proceeds, he casts glances at the people assembled, his gaze sweeping across Grandpierre's face, then moving to Gideon's, on to Reggie's, and finally resting on Sylvie's—all of whom maintain unwavering stares directed at the camera as Tex arrives at the scene. Positioned before Lampert's body, Tex stands momentarily swaying on his feet, until he reaches out instinctively to grip the side of the coffin, using it as a stabilizing support. Having steadied himself, Tex takes the flower from his lapel and, with a deliberate gesture, tosses it into the open box. Observing this, Sylvie gestures toward Reggie, prompting Tex, maintaining his composure, to shift his attention and address Reggie directly. Reggie responds by extracting a letter, unfolding it, and beginning to read aloud. The letter prominently features the Great Seal as its letterhead, with a typed message contained within. Sylvie, meanwhile, leans in to read the message over Reggie's shoulder. As they absorb the contents of the letter, the elevator door closes on them, prompting Reggie to react with urgency. She commences her stride down the hall and finally brings herself to a stop outside a door. Upon entering, she finds the office deserted, the typewriter on the secretary's desk shrouded in a protective plastic cover. Not deterred, Reggie steps inside, her eyes searching for any sign of life, and soon notices that the door to the private office is slightly ajar. At this moment, Bartholomew emerges, appearing in the doorway with a curious look. His appearance is marked by a pale complexion, his grey hair contributing to an impression of someone older than his forty-some years, with 'sickly' being the apt descriptor—his pallor and consumptive look enhancing this impression. Heavy tortoise-framed glasses perch on his nose, frequently slipping down, prompting him to instinctively push them back into position with a swift, unconscious gesture. With a courteous motion, he invites her to enter, stepping aside to clear the way. Inside the modest cubicle, Reggie notices a silver-framed photograph of three children positioned prominently on the desk, alongside an open can of lighter fluid and a crumpled hankie. Bartholomew busies himself with attempting to remove a stain from his necktie, employing the lighter fluid and hankie methodically. When he glances upward at Reggie, he greets her with a silent laugh before resuming his efforts with the tie. Once satisfied, he returns the lighter fluid to a drawer, gives the hankie a sniff to assess its state, decides against using it, and subsequently tucks it into his pocket.

test_cases.name: Micro-Actions -> Macro-Actions
test_cases.description: He pauses by Lampert's body, sneezes repeatedly, and quickly takes a pill. Seeking a seat, he encounters Grandpierre, then retreats to find another place. The door opens to reveal a man in a distinctive velvet-corduroy suit with a yellow flower in his lapel and a bulldurham tag hanging from his pocket. As he approaches the bier with an unsteady gait, he surveys Grandpierre, Gideon, Reggie, and Sylvie, who all watch him. At the coffin, he steadies himself, throws the flower inside, and addresses Reggie, prompted by Sylvie. Reggie retrieves a letter bearing the Great Seal, which Sylvie reads over her shoulder. Transitioning to another scene, Reggie exits the elevator, walks down the hall, and stops at an empty office. She notices the slightly open door to the private office and enters. Bartholomew, a pallid, grey-haired man, greets her and invites her inside. In the small cubicle, he works on a tie stain with lighter fluid and a hankie, briefly acknowledges her with a silent laugh, then tidies up, placing the fluid and hankie away.

test_cases.name: Insert Attributes, Emotions and Scene
test_cases.description: He stops, looks down at Lampert's body, which lies solemnly in the room filled with soft whispers of grief, for a moment, then suddenly sneezes six times in rapid succession, a clear sign of his allergy to dust, often stirred by the old carpets in such places. He takes a small bottle from his pocket, a common antihistamine known for its quick relief, shakes a pill from it, and swallows it dry. He turns and walks back up the aisle of the dimly lit chapel, looking for a place to sit. He comes face to face with Grandpierre, who is known in the community for his intimidating presence and keen observation, stops, and turns to sit somewhere else. Again, the sound of the door opening interrupts them, and they turn to look. The figure of a man, outlined in silhouette against the outside brightness, wears a velvet-corduroy suit, often associated with the eccentric tastes of artists, a string tie, and a bright yellow flower in his lapel, reminiscent of a species that typically blooms in early spring. A bulldurham tag, a nod to a popular brand of loose tobacco often rolled by hand into cigarettes, hangs from his outside breast pocket, dangling from its string. He starts down the aisle toward the bier, camera leading him, and we notice his unsteady gait, indicative of a recent injury or perhaps too much to drink. He turns to look at the others present, moving down the aisle. Grandpierre's face, then Gideon's, a man known for his extensive library and love of rare books, then Reggie's, and Sylvie's—all stare at the camera as Tex arrives. He stands staring at Lampert's body, swaying on his feet until he reaches out and grabs the side of the coffin, crafted from mahogany, to steady himself. Then he takes the flower from his lapel and throws it into the open box, a traditional gesture of farewell. Sylvie points to Reggie, and unruffled, Tex starts over, addressing Reggie this time. She pulls out the letter, stamped with the insignia of a well-respected law firm, and starts to read it. It bears the Great Seal, often symbolizing governmental authority, as a letterhead, and the typed message reads. Sylvie has been reading over Reggie's shoulder. The elevator door closes on them, and Reggie reacts to this, starting down the hall, known for its echoing silence since the office downsizing last month, finally stopping at the door. The office is empty, the typewriter on the secretary's desk covered with its plastic shroud, hinting at the modern shift to digital devices. Reggie enters, looks for somebody, and notices that the door to the private office is slightly ajar, inviting curiosity about what may lie beyond. Bartholomew comes to the door and looks in. He is a pale, grey-haired man who looks, on first examination, older than his forty-odd years; sickly would be the word that describes him best—pallid, consumptive-looking, reminiscent of characters from Victorian literature. He wears heavy tortoise-framed glasses that fall down his nose and cause him to push them back in place every so often with a quick automatic motion. He motions for her to enter, standing aside to let her do so. A small cubicle has a silver-framed photo of three kids on the desk, likely his grandchildren judging by their youthful resemblance. A can of lighter fluid, possibly used to refill an antique lighter kept as a memento, stands open on the desk and a crumpled hankie beside it. He works at a stain on his necktie with lighter fluid and hankie. He looks up at her, laughs silently, then goes back to his tie. He puts away the lighter fluid in a desk drawer, smells the hankie, passes on it, then sticks it in his pocket, a small act of resignation common in those overwhelmed by the monotony of their routine.

He turns to look at the others present moving down the aisle Grandpierre's face then Gideon's then Reggie's and Sylvie's—all stare at the camera as Tex arrives. He stands staring at Lampert's body swaying on his feet until he reaches out and grabs the side of the coffin to steady himself. Then he takes the flower from his lapel and throws it into the open box. Sylvie points to Reggie and unruffled. Tex starts over addressing Reggie this time. She pulls out the letter and starts to read it. It bears the Great Seal as a letterhead and the typed message reads. In the neonlit back alleys of a dystopian metropolis a rogue hacker races against time while being chased by relentless cyborg enforcers their footsteps echoing off rainsoaked pavement. Under the relentless desert sun a lone gunslinger confronts a notorious outlaw at a deserted crossroads both men exchanging steely glances as swirling dust blurs the horizon. On a foggy evening in Victorian London an intrepid detective uncovers a hidden conspiracy among the city’s elite with gaslit streets setting the stage for a race against a mounting darkness. High above a sprawling city skyline a daredevil pilot executes deathdefying maneuvers in a vintage biplane narrowly evading enemy fire as the ground morphs into a dizzying mosaic below. Within the creaking walls of an old countryside manor an estranged family gathers for a mysterious inheritance their hushed whispers and secret glances weaving a tapestry of betrayal and suspense. Amidst the roaring tempest of a stormy ocean a weathered sailor battles nature’s fury on a creaking vessel his resolve as steadfast as the crashing waves that threaten to engulf him. On a bustling 1960s New York street a passionate artist finds unexpected inspiration in the chaotic interplay of urban life capturing moments of love loss and defiant hope on a rainsoaked canvas. Deep in the heart of an enchanted forest a brave knight embarks on a perilous quest to rescue a captive princess facing mythical creatures and treacherous traps with unwavering courage. During a heated political rally in a futuristic city a charismatic leader stokes both hope and dissent. as holographic banners illuminate the night sky and fervent crowds surge with anticipation. In the eerie silence of a postapocalyptic wasteland a hardened survivor scavenges through abandoned ruins haunted by the echoes of a oncethriving civilization now reduced to dust. Beneath the shimmering surface of an underwater kingdom a rebellious mermaid defies ancient traditions to explore forbidden coral reefs and secret caverns brimming with forgotten lore. In the quiet confines of a suburban attic an unassuming teenager stumbles upon a mysterious portal that thrusts him into a surreal world where the very fabric of time and space unravels. On the rugged highlands of Scotland a stoic warrior faces rival clans and ancient curses alike his fierce battle cry resonating across mistcovered moors and turbulent skies. Amid the vibrant chaos of a South American carnival a fearless dancer twirls through streets bursting with color and rhythm each graceful move challenging the rigid boundaries of tradition. During a clandestine meeting in a snowcovered mountain lodge two rival spies exchange cryptic messages hinting at an imminent global conspiracy. their whispered words carried off by the howling wind. Inside a lavish 1920s speakeasy a troubled jazz musician pours his soul into a melancholic melody every note echoing the bittersweet memories of lost love and shattered dreams. In a futuristic space station orbiting a distant planet an intrepid crew confronts bizarre alien phenomena and an enigmatic interstellar threat pushing the limits of human endurance. Amidst the chaos of a raging civil war a compassionate medic races through bombedout streets. his every desperate step a race against time to save lives in the midst of utter devastation. On a sundappled afternoon in a quaint European village an eccentric inventor unveils a groundbreaking contraption that defies conventional physics igniting wonder and skepticism in equal measure. In a bustling marketplace in ancient Persia a cunning street thief navigates labyrinthine alleyways and vibrant bazaars. his calculated every move a daring escape from the everwatchful royal guards. Sylvie has been reading over Reggie's shoulder. The elevator door closes on them and Reggie reacts to this starting down the hall finally stopping at the door. The office is empty. the typewriter on the secretary's desk covered with its plastic shroud. Reggie enters looks for somebody and notices that the door to the private office is slightly ajar. Bartholomew comes to the door and looks in. He is a pale greyhaired man who looks on first examination older than his fortyodd years. sickly would be the word that describes him best—pallid consumptivelooking. He wears heavy tortoiseframed glasses that fall down his nose and because him to push them back in place every so often with a quick automatic motion. He motions for her to enter standing aside to let her do so. A small cubicle has a silverframed photo of three kids on the desk. A can of lighter fluid stands open on the desk and a crumpled hankie beside it. He works at a stain on his necktie with lighter fluid and hankie. He looks up at her laughs silently then goes back to his tie. He puts away the lighter fluid in a desk drawer smells. the hankie passes on it then sticks it in his pocket.

test_cases.description: He stops looks down at Lampert's body for a moment then suddenly sneezes six times in rapid succession. He takes a small bottle from his pocket shakes a pill from it and swallows it dry. He turns and walks back up the aisle looking for a place to sit. He comes face to face with Grandpierre stops and turns to sit somewhere else. Again the sound of the door opening interrupts them and they turn to look. The figure of a man outlined in silhouette against the outside brightness wears a velvetcorduroy suit string tie and a bright yellow flower in his lapel. A bulldurham tag hangs from his outside breast pocket dangling from its string. He starts down the aisle toward the bier camera leading him and we notice his unsteady gait. He wears heavy tortoiseframed glasses that fall down his nose and because him to push them back in place every so often with a quick automatic motion. He motions for her to enter standing aside to let her do so. A small cubicle has a silverframed photo of three kids on the desk. A can of lighter fluid stands open on the desk and a crumpled hankie beside it. He works at a stain on his necktie with lighter fluid and hankie. He looks up at her laughs silently then goes back to his tie. He puts away the lighter fluid in a desk drawer smells. the hankie passes on it then sticks it in his pocket.

He takes a small bottle from his pocket shakes a pill from it and swallows it dry. He turns and walks back up the aisle looking for a place to sit. He works at a stain on his necktie with lighter fluid and hankie. He looks up at her laughs silently then goes back to his tie. He puts away the lighter fluid in a desk drawer smells. the hankie passes on it then sticks it in his pocket.

test_cases.name: Subject-Action-Object Corruption
test_cases.description: The cat pauses, peers up at Watson's shoe for a moment, then suddenly hops five times in slow motion. The cat grabs a toy balloon from its satchel, flips a marble from it, and tosses it skyward. The cat spins and jumps down the tunnel, searching for a spot to dance. The cat bumps into Fitzgerald, pauses, and spins to leap somewhere else. Unexpectedly, the sound of a bell ringing distracts them, and they turn to peek. The outline of a giraffe, silhouetted against the indoor dimness, dons a leather-denim jacket, rope gloves, and a dull purple feather in its cap. A bandanna tag droops from its inner hip pocket, swaying from its chain. The giraffe rolls up the path toward the pie, whiskers guiding it, and we notice its steady trot. The giraffe spins to observe the creatures gathered, striding up the path. Fitzgerald's eyes, then Harold's, then Sandy's, and Lucy's—all gaze at the whiskers as Max arrives. The giraffe stands eyeing Watson's shoe, tipping on its toes until it lunges out and clutches the rim of the drum to balance itself. Then the giraffe snatches the feather from its cap and tosses it into the closed crate. Lucy gestures to Sandy, and amused, Max drifts over, whispering to Sandy this time. Sandy pulls out the map and begins to fold it. It displays the Large Emblem as a watermark, and the scribbled note scribbles. Lucy has been peeking over Sandy's arm. The window curtain sways over them, and Sandy sighs to this, rolling down the corridor, hesitantly pausing at the window. The garden is crowded, the microphone on the announcer's podium draped with its velvet cape. Sandy steps in, searches for anyone, and observes that the window to the public lounge is slightly wide. Theodore stumbles to the window and peers out. Theodore is a tall, gold-haired woman who appears, on second glance, younger than her sixty or so years; athletic would be the term that suits her best—lively, sprightly-looking. She sports light wooden-framed goggles that perch on her chin and make her adjust them upward every now and then with a slow deliberate gesture. She gestures for him to exit, leaning aside to watch him do so. A large room has a golden-framed portrait of four dogs on the podium. A bottle of suntan lotion lies closed on the podium and a neat scarf beside it. She fiddles at a mark on her handkerchief with suntan lotion and scarf. She glances over at him, chuckles softly, then returns to her scarf. She places the suntan lotion in a drawer, sniffs the scarf, skips it, then slips it in her bag.

test_cases.name: Complete Corruption
test_cases.description: The film starts with a man waking up in a small apartment. He prepares coffee and checks his phone for messages. There are none, so he heads out to catch a bus. On the way, he passes a neighbor who greets him briefly. At the bus stop, he notices a group of students talking about an upcoming test. He boards the bus and sits near the back, watching the city pass by outside the window. After a few stops, he gets off near a large office building. He enters the lobby and goes through security. He rides an elevator to the tenth floor, where he works as an assistant. His manager asks him to prepare some documents for a meeting later in the day. He collects files from different departments and organizes them in a conference room. Another employee asks him for help with a software issue, so he takes a few minutes to fix it. Then he returns to the conference room to double-check everything before the meeting begins. The meeting starts at noon. Several people join via video call, and others sit around the table. The manager outlines the project goals, and each team member shares updates on their tasks. There are questions about deadlines and budgets, but no big surprises. After an hour, they end the call. The manager thanks everyone and leaves. The assistant cleans up the room, collects leftover notes, and heads back to his desk. During lunch, he walks to a nearby café, where he orders a simple meal. He eats alone and checks social media on his phone. After lunch, he returns to the office and finishes smaller tasks, such as sending emails and filing paperwork. He also helps a coworker carry boxes of supplies to another floor. Later in the afternoon, the manager calls him in to discuss next week's schedule. They go over a few changes, and the assistant updates the calendar. When the workday ends, he logs off his computer and leaves the building. Outside, he walks a few blocks to meet a friend. They chat about weekend plans and decide to see a film on Saturday. The assistant then heads home on a crowded bus. At his apartment, he sorts his mail, feeds a pet cat, and warms up leftovers for dinner. He watches a short news segment on TV, then checks his phone again. A message from his friend confirms their plan for the weekend. He feels relieved to have something to look forward to. The film ends with him preparing for bed, setting an alarm, and turning off the lights. He reflects briefly on the day, thinking about his tasks, his quiet home, and the plans ahead.

test_cases.name: Summarization
test_cases.description: He pauses over Lampert's body, sneezes six times, and takes a pill. Seeking a seat, he encounters Grandpierre and moves on. A man in a velvet-corduroy suit with a yellow flower and a bulldurham tag enters. He stumbles down the aisle, steadies himself at Lampert's coffin, and throws the flower in. Sylvie signals to Reggie, who begins reading a letter with the Great Seal. As the elevator closes, Reggie follows a hallway to an empty office. She notices the private office door ajar, where Bartholomew, a sickly, pale man in his forties with glasses, appears. He gestures her in, working on a necktie stain with lighter fluid. After laughing silently, he tidies up and pockets a crumpled hankie.
